title: Introduction
body:
Adapt allows you to combine Text and Graphic components on the scrolling page to create rich and varied learning experiences. In addition, a wide range of interactive components are also available to help encourage deeper engagement with the material.

These presentation components can be structured in any way to help you create learning experiences that meet the needs of your learners.

In addition, if your course is being launched from an LMS or LRS, you can personalise the course content by having the learner's name dynamically displayed in the body, instruction or feedback text.

title: Introduction
body:
In this module you will learn the basics of nutrition. You will learn about nutrients, nutrient-density and energy. You will also learn about the amounts of nutrients you should eat and how to interpret food labels.

Why Should I Learn About Nutrition?

Nutrition is a complex topic, from the broad ideas to the tiniest details of what we eat and drink and how these affect our health. This course focusses on the most important topics that can help in your daily dietary decisions.

Studies show that, generally, the more a person knows and understands about nutrition, the better their dietary choices.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
After completing this module you will be able to:
  • Summarise the categories of nutrients.
  • Define nutrient density and identify nutrient dense foods.
  • Estimate your energy (calorie) needs.
  • Identify or estimate the energy (calories) in various foods.

title: Scenario: George
body: Here we'll meet George, a farmer who lives alone and has a stroke when out working on his farm.
instruction: Click or tap the play button to start the video.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody: George is a 71-year-old farmer who lives alone. One afternoon when working on his farm, he begins to feel unwell and his vision becomes a little blurry. He falls and realises that his left side feels unusual. Luckily, he is able to reach his phone and dial 112. An ambulance arrives and takes him to hospital. During the journey and after he arrives at the hospital he begins to feel a little better and his vision improves. The doctors ask him lots of questions, examine him and do blood tests and a brain scan. He is diagnosed with a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) or 'mini-stroke' and makes a complete recovery. While in hopsital the doctors start him on some new medications and he also meets with the dietician who tells him lots of information about what foods he should and shouldn't eat. After returning home, George feels overwhelmed. He really doesn't want to have another stroke. It all sounded manageable when he was in hospital but now he doesn't know how to make the right changes to his diet and lifestyle.

title: Nutrients
body:
Nutrients are substances obtained from food and used in the body to provide energy and materials for growth, maintenance, and repair of the body's tissues.

Carbohydrates, fats and proteins are the energy-containing nutrients.

They provide the energy we need (often represented as calories) for many of our bodily functions.

Vitamins, minerals and water are the other nutrients and they do not provide energy. We will discuss them later.

title: Carbohydrates
body:
Often shortened to 'carbs', carbohydrates include starches, sugars and fibre.

Starches are 'complex' carbohydrates. This means that they are larger and take longer for the body to break down. They are found in cereals such as wheat, barley, rice, corn and oats.

Sugars are 'simple' carbohydrates. They are smaller than starches and the body breaks them down quickly. The simplest forms are glucose, fructose (found in fruits) and galactose (found in peas).

The other forms are sucrose (table sugar), lactose (found in dairy) and maltose (found in sprouted grains). These last three forms are formed from different combinations of glucose, fructose and galactose.

title: Fibre
body:
Fibre is the part of plant foods that cannot be digested, it passes through the body unchanged.

There are two different types of fiber, soluble (which dissolves in water) and insoluble (which does not). Both types help to regulate our sugar levels by slowing down digestion.

The soluble kind often has a gel-like consistency (for example in cooked porridge/oatmeal). This type of fiber provides energy for the healthy bacteria in your gut. The insoluble kind is often known as 'bulking' fiber and helps to prevent constipation.

The picture opposite shows some examples of high fibre foods.
What are the three different types of carbohydrates?
instruction: Choose one option and select Submit.

title: Fats
body:
Fats are also known as lipids or fatty acids, and come in multiple forms: polyunsaturated, unsaturated, saturated and hydrogenated (also known as trans fats).

Saturation refers to the chemical structure of the fats but there are some easier ways to tell whether a fat is saturated or unsaturated.

General rules:
  1. Animal fats are saturated and MOST plant fats are unsaturated.
  2. Saturated fats are solid at room temperature, unsaturated fats are liquid (pourable) at room temperature.
So, if a fat is liquid at room temperature and is plant-based, it is probably unsaturated.

Hydrogenation is the process of 'saturating' an unsaturated fat. This creates a hydrogenated or trans fat which is more stable and solid at room temperature. This process occurs very rarely in nature.

title: Benefits and Risks of Fats
body:
Unsaturated and polyunsaturated fats are associated with a lower risk of strokes and other vascular diseases.

Saturated fats are associated with higher risk of these diseases. Saturated fats are created in sufficient amounts in the body, so they are not required in the diet.

Trans fats are not created by, or required by the human body. They carry the same risk as saturated fats but with zero benefits and they should be avoided.

title: Cholesterol
body:
Cholesterol is a type of fat that is important for various functions in the body. However, the human body cannot convert cholesterol into energy.

Despite lots of warning about eating cholesterol, it doesn't have much impact on the cholesterol in your blood. The liver creates much more cholesterol than the average diet. The cholesterol that your doctor checks is actually cholesterol packaged together with other fats and proteins to make the 'good' and 'bad' cholesterol in your blood.

Saturated fats increase the bad cholesterol in your blood, so focus on limiting saturated fats and excluding trans-fats rather than cholesterol.
Which of these is NOT a type of fat.
instruction: Choose one option and select Submit.

title: Proteins
body:
Proteins are made of chains of amino acids of various lengths. These chains can be short or contain 100s of amino acids. Amino acids and proteins are important for most bodily functions.

There are about 20 common amino acids. 9 of these must be obtained from the diet and are 'essential'. The others can be made by the body.

Protein Quality

High-quality proteins contain all the essential amino acids that we need. These are generally derived from animals.

Plant-based proteins usually lack one or more amino acids. However, these can be paired with another protein source which contains the missing amino acid. These are known as complementary proteins and is an important concept when eating a plant-based diet.

Beans and rice is an example of a common pairing. Beans are low in the amino acid methionine which is found in rice and other grains.

Other common pairings include:
  • Grains with dairy
  • Dairy with nuts
  • Dairy with seeds and legumes
What are complementary proteins?
instruction: Choose one option and select Submit.

_items.text: Proteins which are particularly good for your health.
Pairs of proteins that, together, contain all essential amino acids.
The combination of proteins from animals and plants.
Groups of proteins that contain short and long chains of amino acids.

title: Vitamins, Minerals and Water
body:
The previous three nutrients all provide energy.

Vitamins, minerals and water do not, but they help in many different processes in the body, including helping to release the energy from carbohydrates, protein and fat.
instruction: Select the next and back arrows to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Vitamins
_items.body:
There 13 vitamins: A, D, E, K, C and 8 different B vitamins. All are fragile and can becoming damaged during cooking.

The first 4 (A, D, E, and K) are fat soluble and require fat in order to be absorbed, one reason why fat is important for bodily functions.

_items.title: Minerals
_items.body:
Minerals are elements like sodium, potassium and calcium, and are important for all functions in the body.

Unlike vitamins, there are not fragile and not harmed by cooking, though the chemical reactions in cooking can join them together in different ways.

16 minerals are essential to human nutrition, including sodium, potassium, calcium, chloride, and magnesium.

_items.title: Water
_items.body:
Water is necessary for every bodily function and is particularly important for maintaining body temperature.

The human body is approximately 60% water.

title: Simplifying Nutrition
body:
As I said at the beginning, nutrition is a complex subject, even when trying to keep it simple. However, there are two concepts that can help: variety and nutrient-density.

Variety

Variety is the easiest way to meet all of your nutrient requirements. This included variety in your sources of carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins and minerals. We will be discussing this further in the next module about the Mediterranean diet.

Nutrient-density

Nutrient-density is another concept that can simplify things. This is the idea of eating foods that contain the most nutrients for the least energy (calories). We will talk about energy in the next section but nutrient-density is why so many diets recommend eating unprocessed foods. They tend to contain the most nutrients.

Processing tends to remove nutrients from food and ingredients are often added to processed foods that have little nutritional value but may add lots of calories.

The take-home message is that if you eat a variety of unprocessed, nutrient-dense foods without exceeding your energy requirements and saturated fat limit, you are likely meeting your nutritional requirements in a way that is healthy and will help prevent diseases, including strokes.
What are nutrient-dense foods?
instruction: Choose one option and select Submit.

_items.text: Foods with the most nutrients for the least energy.
Foods that are high in protein and low in fat.
Foods with lots of carbohydrate, fat and protein.

title: Energy
body:
Why Learn About Energy?

There is a lot of information available about calories and their impact on your health, particularly when it comes to gaining and losing weight.

In order to lose weight you must be in an energy-deficit, meaning that you use more energy than you take in. Whatever diet you are on, this fact remains true.

This section explains how to find the energy content of any food with a nutrition label, how to estimate the energy content of other foods, and how to calculate your own energy requirements.
What is an energy-deficit?
instruction: Choose one option and select Submit.

_items.text: When you are tired all the time.
When you take in less energy than your body needs.
When the food you eat contains very little energy.
When you don't feel full after eating.

body:
In nutrition, the energy that food contains is measured in calories or Joules. Since calories and Joules are very small measurements, energy is usually shown in kilocalories and kiloJoules (kcal, kJ) which is 1000 calories or Joules. When we talk about calories, we are usually talking about kilocalories. This is why we might say a person needs 2,000 calories per day, when really we mean 2,000 kilocalories!

How do we know the amount of energy in food?

A bomb calorimeter is used to burn foods and measure the heat energy produced. This is measured in Joules or calories. This is where the energy information on nutrition labels comes from.
An online recipe for spaghetti bolognese states that one portion contains 600 calories. How many kilocalories is that?
instruction: Choose one option and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: Well done! That’s correct. In everyday writing and speech, when we talk about calories, we actually mean kilocalories. Kilocalories are generally only used in scientific writing and nutritional labels. If the recipe actually meant 'calories', one portion would be 500,000 kilocalories!

_incorrect.final: Sorry. That’s incorrect. In everyday speech, when we talk about calories, we actually mean kilocalories. Kilocalories are generally only used in scientific writing and nutritional labels. If the recipe actually meant 'calories', one portion would be 500,000 kilocalories!

title: Energy in Foods
body:
Remember from the previous section that carbohydrates, protein and fat are the only energy containing nutrients.

1 gram of carbohydrates contains 4 kcal.

1 gram of protein also contains 4kcal.

1 gram of fat contains 9 kcal. Note that fat contains more than double the energy of carbohydrates and protein, i.e., it has more than double the caloric-density.
How many kilocalories are in 100 grams of fat?
instruction: Choose one option and select Submit.

title: Energy Calculations
instruction: Click the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Basal Metabolic Rate
_items.body:
BMR is the energy required just to maintain life, without any physical activity.

There are various calculations but the easiest are as follows:

Men: 24kcal per kg of body-weight per day
Women: 23kcal per kg of body-weight per day

Example 1: An 80kg Man

80 x 24 = 1920 kcal/day

Example 2: A 60kg Woman

60 x 23 = 1380 kcal/day

_items.title: Total Energy Expenditure
_items.body:
Calculating your exact energy requirements requires a complicated calculation but the following table shows the average energy expenditure based on age and activity level.

The more accurate calculation is available HERE but isn't really necessary in most cases.

PAL values relate to how active a person is
  • 1.4 = low active or sedentary.
  • 1.6 = moderately active
  • 1.8 = active.
  • 2.0 = very active.

_items.title: Tasks
_items.body:
1. Calculate your own Basal Metabolic Rate.
  2. Find your Total Energy Expenditure on the table.
  3. Compare the two answers.
The difference between the two is how much energy you burn due to your activity level.

title: Recommended Intakes
body: Recommended intakes (RIs) are the amounts of carbohydrates, protein and fats that we should eat, as recommended by the EFSA.
instruction: Click the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Energy
_items.body:
The RIs on all nutritional labels are based on a 2000kcal diet. Recall from the previous section that everyone's energy requirements are different. Your task at the end of this section will be to calculate the amounts of fat, protein and carbohydrates you require, based on the Total Energy Expenditure you calculated. Don't worry about the calculations, there will be a handy table to help!

Each recommendation is slightly different. For fat it is an upper limit (i.e., you should eat less than the recommendation). For carbohydrates it is a lower limit. Protein is a little more complicated as there are potential (but currently unproven) risk of diets very high in protein. So for protein there is a range from minimum requirements to the maximum that is likely to be safe.

_items.title: Carbohydrates
_items.body:
The recommended lower limit for carbohydrates is 52% (260g of a 2000kcal diet). The reason for this being a lower limit is that it is thought to be safer to receive the energy from carbohydrates than from excessive fat or protein. Unprocessed sources of carbohydrates are often also high in fibre, unlike many sources of protein and fats (except for pulses).

The recommended upper limit for total sugars is 18% (90g in a 2000kcal diet).

Added sugars are included in this 18%; these are table sugar and sugars found in fruit juice, honey and syrups. Added sugars should be kept as low as possible as they increase the risk of dental caries and various diseases. The upper limit for added sugars is 9% (45g in a 2000kcal diet).

_items.title: Fat
_items.body:
The recommended upper limit for total fat is 31.5%. This is 70g in a 2000kcal diet.

The upper limit for saturated fat is 9% (20g in a 2000kcal diet). Remember that the body creates enough saturated fat for all bodily functions so aiming for as little saturated fat as possible is ideal.

Avoid hydrogenated or trans fats altogether.

_items.title: Protein
_items.body:
Protein is a little bit more complicated. This is due to potential but unproven risk of diets very high in protein and the proven risk of diets low in protein, particularly in older people.

There are three calculations to be aware of:
  • 0.66g/kg/day = likely to meet the requirements of half the population
  • 0.83g/kg/day = likely to meet the requirements of 97.5% of the population
  • 1.2g/kg/day = the advised maximum amount of protein that is still likely to be safe
The RI for protein is 10% (50g in a 2000kcal diet). This should be seen as a lower limit as diets in older people are often low in protein and diets of up to 20% protein as safe.

_items.title: Task
_items.body: Use the table provided to work out the amount of fat, carbohydrates and protein you should eat, based on your Total Energy Expenditure.

title: Nutrient Reference Values
body: Nutrient reference values (NRVs) were created as guidelines for nutritional labels but are good estimates of the amount of vitamins and minerals we should eat.
instruction: Click the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Vitamins and Minerals
_items.body:
You may recall that vitamins and minerals do not supply energy but are still really important. Nutrient Reference Values (NRVs) are used on food labels to give general advice to the public on the amounts of each vitamin and mineral. However, there are a number of issues with these values:
  1. Some values are lower than the minimum recommendations.
  2. Most of the values are on the low side of recommendations and a lot lower than the amounts that are safe for our diet. For example, Vitamin D deficiency is widespread. The NRV for Vitamin D is 15 micrograms per day, yet the recommended upper limit for Vitamin D is 100 micrograms per day.
My advice in the case of NRVs is that, unless you have been advised you are low in a particular vitamin or mineral and want to eat foods high in that nutrient, you should ignore them and instead, focus on eating a varied diet.

_items.title: Salt
_items.body:
Salt is the one mineral that no one should ignore. Salt is the combination of sodium and chloride. Note that sodium does not appear on the NRV list; instead it is included in Salt on the Reference Intake label to highlight its importance.

The RI for salt is an upper limit of 6g. Currently in the EU the average salt intake is 8-11g per day. Diets high in salt are associated with high blood pressure, heart disease, strokes and other vascular diseases.

Some Ways to Reduce Your Salt Intake

  1. Use pepper and other spices to season your food.
  2. Use alternatives such as Lo-Salt, which contains much less sodium.
  3. Limit your intake of processed and fast-food as they tend to caontain a lot of salt.
Over a short period of time (days to weeks) on a low salt diet, your tastebuds become more sensitive to salt, so foods taste saltier.

_items.title: Water
_items.body:
The recommended water intake is 2 - 3.1L per day for women and 2.5 - 4L for men, depending on your activity level. This may seem like a lot of water but this includes the water content of foods. One study found that in the average diet we get from 20-40% of our water from food. Another advantage of eating a varied diet of nutrient-dense foods is that they tend to have a higher water content than processed foods.

For example, cucumber and lettuce are approximately 96% water, carrots are 90% water, oranges are 87% water, apples are 86% water, boiled chicken eggs are 75% water, cooked potatoes are 75% water and cooked rice is 65% water. Most cooked meat are 60% water.

At the other end of the scale, a cheese pizza is 38% water, a pork pie is 32% water, a Mars bar is 7% water and digestive biscuits are 2.8% water.

Taking all this into account, if eating a varied, nutrient-dense diet:
  • Women should drink at least 1.2 - 2L of fluids per day, depending on activity levels.
  • Men should drink at least 1.5 - 2.5L of fluids per day, depending on activity levels.

title: Slider
body: Working memory is thought to be responsible for our ability to temporarily hold and manipulate information, but according to a paper by Miller (1956) what ‘magic number’ describes its capacity?
instruction: Drag the slider to make your choice and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct answer feedback.

Yes, that’s right. According to Miller’s paper 7 +/- 2 chunks of information was the limited capacity of working memory. Various theories from the field of cognitive psychology such as Miller’s magical number, chunking, the forgetting curve and spaced repetition have all influenced learning theory over the last 50 years or so.

Component facts: The correct answer for a Slider component can be an exact number or a range. In this instance we have set the correct answer to a range of 5-9 due to the correct answer being seven plus or minus two. Component is either single or spanned.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect answer feedback.

Sorry, that’s not right. According to Miller’s paper 7 +/- 2 chunks of information was the limited capacity of working memory. Various theories from the field of cognitive psychology such as Miller’s magical number, chunking, the forgetting curve and spaced repetition have all influenced learning theory over the last 50 years or so.

Component facts: The correct answer for a Slider component can be an exact number or a range. In this instance we have set the correct answer to a range of 5-9 due to the correct answer being seven plus or minus two. Component is either single or spanned.
